diagrams.description: Databases evolved from file systems to sophisticated distributed data management platforms. Early data storage used flat files and sequential access (1950s-1960s). The hierarchical database model emerged with IMS (1966) organizing data in tree structures. The network database model (1969) introduced many-to-many relationships. Edgar Codd's relational model paper (1970) revolutionized database theory with mathematical foundations. SQL development at IBM (1970s) provided standard query language. The relational database management systems commercialized in the late 1970s with Oracle and Ingres. Object-oriented databases emerged in the 1980s supporting complex data types. SQL standardization (1986) promoted interoperability across vendors. Data warehousing concepts developed in the 1990s for business intelligence. The term NoSQL appeared around 2009 addressing web-scale data challenges. MongoDB (2009) popularized document databases. Apache Cassandra provided distributed column-family storage. NewSQL databases (2010s) combined relational guarantees with NoSQL scalability. Cloud database services like Amazon RDS transformed deployment. Today's databases integrate serverless architectures, multi-model capabilities, blockchain databases, and AI-powered query optimization.

timeline
    title Databases Evolution
    1950s-1960s : Flat File Systems
                : Sequential access storage
    1966 : Hierarchical Model IMS
         : Tree structure organization
    1969 : Network Database Model
         : Many-to-many relationships
    1970 : Codd's Relational Model
         : Mathematical foundations
    1970s : SQL Development
          : Standard query language
    Late 1970s : RDBMS Commercialization
               : Oracle & Ingres
    1980s : Object-Oriented Databases
          : Complex data types
    1986 : SQL Standardization
         : Vendor interoperability
    1990s : Data Warehousing
          : Business intelligence
    2009 : NoSQL Emergence
         : Web-scale challenges
    2009 : MongoDB Launch
         : Document database popularity
    2010s : NewSQL Databases
          : Relational + NoSQL scalability
    2020s : Serverless & Multi-Model
          : Cloud-native AI optimization
